RE: License#: CB630201414
Dear Ms. Vaseau:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/22/2025. A exit conference was held with the agency on 8/25/2025. Due to the violations of
applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan
is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the WOC area manager, Shay Mavis, at 269-243-2725.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the
person has not been named in a central registry
case as the perpetrator of child abuse or neglect
in Michigan or in any state where the person
lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
In one of four new employee records reviewed where the employee was a rehire
the record did not show documentation of a children service’s clearance.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
Two of four open foster home records reviewed showed the agency's
recommendation to the department did not occur within 15 days of the respective
foster homes’ 8/5/2025 and 8/23/2025 licensing expiration dates.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:

(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
One of one borrowed home records reviewed did not show that all of the agency’s
policies and procedures were reviewed with the foster parent.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social
services worker that has children placed in the
home.
In one of five special evaluation records reviewed, the report did not show
documentation that all workers who had children in the home received a copy of
the report.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be
provided to department; failure of licensee to
cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested,
the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall
be properly safeguarded by the child care organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:
One of five special evaluations records reviewed indicated CPS was involved in
the investigation.

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
In two of eight open child records reviewed where the child was replaced, the
record did not show documentation of consideration of all the factors identified in
R400.12404(4).
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant
parties, including the child or infant, which
includes an explanation as to why the change is
necessary.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed, where the child was replaced,
the record did not show documentation of preparation related to all parties for the
child’s placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
In three of eight open foster child records reviewed, where the respective child
was replaced in two, and had an initial placement in the other, the record did not
show documentation that the caregiver was provided with all available known
information about the child's health.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.

In three of eight open foster child records reviewed, where the respective child
was replaced in two, and had an initial placement in the other, the record did not
show documentation that the caregiver was provided with any known history of
abuse or neglect of the child, all known emotional and psychological factors
relating to care of the child, all known behaviors of the child, and circumstances
necessitating placement or replacement of the child.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed the respective child’s record did
not show that all treatments plans were reviewed and signed timely by all parties.
Repeat Violation Estalished:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
Renewal 2023, cited under 722-8D, CAP approved 10/1/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an adoptive
application is provided.
One of four adoption family records reviewed where the family was approved for
adoption; and two of two denied adoptive family records reviewed did not show
documentation of an application. Another adoptive family’s record showed the
family received an adoption application prior to orientation.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(2) The orientation must include a review of all the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and
procedures.

Four of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show documentation that the
family was provided with a copy of the agency's policies and procedures.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
In two of six adoptive family records reviewed where an adoption application was
documented, the family's adoption assessment was not completed within 90 days
of the family 3/4/2024 and 10/30/2024 respective adoption application date.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP Approved 11/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
Three of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show documentation that
the adoptive family received a copy of the family adoption assessment upon its
completion.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 10/1/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel records: the agency was apprised it shall
ensure that it can be determined from the references that it was received
prior to the employee's date of hire.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:

• R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel records: the agency was advised that a date
and the name of the person completing the reference may aid it in
documenting compliance with the rule.
• R400.12417(1)(a)-(i) Foster parent information: The agency was advised to
add the exact rule title to its intake placement/replacement tool form and or
utilizing the DHS-3307, and DHS-3307A tool to complete with caregivers
around placement and replacement as it may aid it in documenting
compliance to this rule.
• R400.12326(1)(f) borrowed home: The agency was advised that creating a
policy and procedure acknowledgement checklist, which lists all policies it
reviews and provided the foster parent(s); and which is signed and dated by
the agency and the foster parent(s) may aid in documenting compliance to
this rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
This incident related to allegations that the foster mother, after arriving at the foster
child’s school due to the child having behavior concerns, spat in the child’s face,
slapped him, and placed her foot on his stomach. The special evaluation
substantiated the allegations and a violation of the foster home rules of behavior
management, and foster parent qualification were established. The foster children
were removed from the foster home; and revocation of the family’s foster home
license was recommended.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to allegations that the foster mother grabbed her five-year-old
foster child by the hair and pushed his head aggressively and cursed him, after the
child pulled her hair. The special evaluation concluded with the establishment of a
behavior management rule violation; the foster mom admitted to using profanity
toward the child, in the presence of the child’ birth parent. A corrective action plan
was completed with the foster parents. The corrective action plan included the
foster parents re-reviewing the agency’s foster parent agency agreement, behavior
management policy and completing a behavior management questionnaire.

The agency adhered to all departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation, except R400.12327 and MCL 722.120(3) for which the agency
received a citation.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Interim
inspection completed on 9/3/2024; and CAP approve 11/27/2024. In that 2024
inspection, the agency received 18 rule citations of which 10 were repeat
violations for the reporting period (7 specifically from 2023). During this 2025
inspection, 17 rule violations were established; and 5 are repeat rule violations
from 2024.
The agency implemented its 2024 corrective action plan and made progress with it
as demonstrated by the lowered number of repeat citations. Conversely, the
number of individual cases cited per rule increased by 2 in 3 of the 5 rules cited;
and decreased by 5 and 1 respectively related to the other 2 rules cited. The
agency reported it struggles with creating a CAP every year, because it is hard to
determine if the action steps put in place will be effective in bringing about the
change it wants. The agency reported the CAP it developed in 2024 had some
good goals and action steps, but it also had some that did not bring about
improvement, once they started to implement them. Notwithstanding this
realization, the agency reported it will continue to review and work on enhanced
methods to bring about rule compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 8/14/2025. The chief
administrator (CA) reported on the prior year's violations and the action steps it put
in place to achieve compliance. The CA also indicated systematic factors that
impacted rule compliance, such as child welfare worker burnout, mental health
challenges for children being served, and those factors’ impact on worker
longevity in foster care positions; and the Department of Child Welfare Licensing
(DCWL) rules and the Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS) policies
(such as KPIs-key performance indicators) not always aligning. Therein with the
latter, the agency may experience compliance related to KPIs (i.e. achieving 80%
or higher on a standard), while being in noncompliance related to DCWL rules if
one case is cited (/because 100% isn’t achieved). The agency reported it shall
continue to advocate for DCWL to follow KPI requirements. As mentioned above,
the agency reported that developing corrective action plans has been a struggle;
they also report they will continue to put action steps in place, and will work with
staff around those action steps in an effort to increase and maintain rule
compliance, The agency also reported it was helpful to have CAP follow-ups
during the last 6 months to ensure steps were being followed; and that they
expected less rule violations as a result of the CAP.
The agency further reported that despite continued staff retention challenges in
some position areas; they are trying to address the mental health and stress

aspect on workers by providing aid and compensating workers in way that they
can. The agency identified the main strengths of the agency’s as its stability of
managerial staff, and its development of monitoring and tracking mechanisms to
assist around due dates. Areas for improvement identified was around the new
licensing supervisor getting acclimated to her role, and adoption related tasks
around assessment timeframes.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of its 2024/2025 annual budget; and 9/30/2024,
independent financial audit. A review of these documents did not show any areas
of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, program director, licensing
supervisor, and foster care supervisors during the entrance conference, I
interviewed two foster care workers and an adoption worker. The staff interviewed
reported being appreciative of the size of the agency, in that its smallness offers a
family-like aspect, and there is team encouragement and support. Areas for
improvement centered on the agency acquiring more staff to help reduce case
activities; and continued improved communication with managers.
Description of Agency Walk Through
During a walkthrough of the facility no concerns were revealed. The agency’s
records are securely stored, and there appears to be sufficient equipment for staff.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Two safety alerts were identified:
Safety Alert #1 received 6/6/2025: The child stated when he gets in trouble. The
foster parent spanks him with an open hand on his butt.
Resolution: The agency opened a separate evaluation related to the allegation; and
effective 6/6/2024 established a safety plan with the foster parent that she will not
use physical discipline techniques. The foster parent will use removal of privileges,
such as restriction of television.
Safety Alert # 2 received 6/24/2025: The window screens in the children’s bedrooms
are missing. The missing screens do not allow a fan to be placed in the windows;
and due to the extreme heat the two boys are not able to sleep in their bedroom.
Resolution: On 6/27/2025 the agency reported the window screens were delivered
and installed by the caregivers. Two screens were installed in each of the children's
bedrooms; and the children are able to safely and comfortably sleep in the bedrooms.
The agency provided photos showing the window screens installed, and one photo
showing a window fan unit installed that is able to be utilized to keep the room cooler.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
August 30, 2025
